author: timbeiko
content:
Looking at this poll and the above, the most popular terms seem to be `baseFeePerGas`, `gasFeeCap` and `gasTipCap`. This would make it clear that the base fee is `PerGas` and would maintain compatibility with the other transaction fields (`gasUsed`, `gasLimit`, etc.). The naming for the block header field doesn't "match" the one for the txn fields, but given those are two different objects, that seems fine? 

Any major objections to using these? If not, we can add a paragraph to 1559 saying these are the canonical names.

author: pietjepuk
content: Does that mean that `gasTipCap` is not per unit of gas? I'm confused now

author: lightclient
content: no it is, gas at the beginning is just denoting the unit, same as `gasPrice`

author: lightclient
content: i think we should work on coming up with a gas-prefixed version of `baseFee`, it seems weird to deviate from the naming convention once

author: timbeiko
content: `gasBaseFee` ? I kind of like it. It reads as "the base fee for gas", which is what the value in the block will represent.

author: pietjepuk
content: Sounds good enough. At least it's consistent üòÖ

author: sky.cactus
content: It is the word `price` that denotes the unit here.

author: sky.cactus
content: ETH Price means "how many of <unknown> is 1 ETH worth".  The word "price" is assumes the denomination is well known via context.

author: sky.cactus
content: `gasPrice` is saying "the cost of gas denominated in *something*.

author: sky.cactus
content: `gasCap` is saying "maximum amount of gas".

author: sky.cactus
content: Which is why I'm pretty strongly against these names.  They are extremely unclear.

author: sky.cactus
content: `gasLimit` and `gas*Cap` are way too ambiguous IMO.

author: sky.cactus
content: Remember, the people reading this are not necessarily Ethereum experts.  They may be new developers working in the ecosystem, or even end users if the API variable names end up exposed to users due to poor UX (which happens *all* the time).

author: sky.cactus
content: `gasTipCap` is the worst of the three IMO as it doesn't have any indication whatsoever that it is "per gas".

author: sky.cactus
content: And in fact, if you read it naively (without all of the context that core devs have), you will assume that it is the maximum gas tip you will pay" and an appropriate value for such a field is like 0.01 * 10**18 or something, not 0.0000001 * 10**18 or something.

author: sky.cactus
content: `gasFeeCap` is also extremely ambiguous actually, since `Fee` doesn't come with any contextual connotation about units like price does.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would be *marginally* more OK with `gasPriceCap` and `gasPriorityPriceCap` (I still hate `tip` because its English definition doesn't align at all with what it is representing) because at least they have an indication that we are talking about a "per x" thing and not a total.

author: pietjepuk
content: I don't mind postfixing with "PerGas"; the only counterargument is the lack of not having done so for existing fields. But if those can't be changed, I'd strongly prefer being consistent with the naming of the new fields (be it "<something something>PerGas" or "gas<something something>")

author: timbeiko
content:
So, perhaps we're down to two options:

1Ô∏è‚É£ `gasBaseFee`, `gasFeeCap`, `gasTipCap`
2Ô∏è‚É£ `baseFeePerGas`, `feeCapPerGas`, `feeTipPerGas` OR `priorityFeePerGas`

author: timbeiko
content: It would be nice to resolve this in the next ~24h so we're not blocked on it to spec JSON RPC üòÖ

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the root cause of disagreement is very similar to one that comes up frequently, which is "who is the target demographic".

author: sky.cactus
content: If the target demographic is "current Ethereum developers" then consistency with history wins.  If the target demographic is "future Ethereum developers" then I think ease of understanding wins.

author: pietjepuk
content: Even "me in a year from now" will be very confused if both "gasFeeCap" and "gasLimit" exist

author: sky.cactus
content: How do people feel about renaming `gasPrice` to `feePerGas`, and starting to accept/send it over JSON-RPC and then in a year (or maybe 2) we drop `gasPrice`?

author: sky.cactus
content: That would give us eventual consistency and readability/grokability.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, if our plan is to deprecate legacy transactions in a similar time frame, it may not be worth it.

author: timbeiko
content: Yeah, that would be my feeling: it will likely break a bunch of stuff and may be redundant.

author: timbeiko
content: I actually think it may be a positive for 1559 fields to be slightly different, so you don't get mixed up with legacy txn fields

author: sky.cactus
content: Like renaming `gas` to `gasLimit`.  üòÑ

author: sky.cactus
content: JS libraries like `ethers` call it `gasLimit` because `gas` was too confusing for developers and not verbose enough.

author: sky.cactus
content: We could "make it official" and say that if you are sending a 1559 transaction then you have to send `gasLimit, feeCapPerGas, feeXPerGas` and if you are sending a legacy transaction you have to send `gas, gasPrice`.

author: sky.cactus
content: This starts to lean toward what Juan (not sure if they are in Discord) was arguing in call about how we should consider enveloping so each transaction can have its own fields without worrying about alignment between different transaction types.

author: timbeiko
content:
So, looking at folks who voted and the current conversation, the following option was already quite popular: `baseFeePerGas`, `feeCapPerGas`, `feeTipPerGas` OR `priorityFeePerGas`

<@!543900561460822016> and <@!758579010027782144> were the two only client devs who favored `baseFee` over `baseFeePergas`, while `gasFeeCap` + `gasTipCap` were favored by a bit more folks: <@!508125616940515329> <@!543900561460822016> <@!758579010027782144> and Geth, who proposed it. 

It seems like we can go around in circles here a lot üòÖ  Do either of the folks tagged above want to "move to the other side" so we get consensus? Otherwise, we can perhaps schedule a sync call tomorrow or Wednesday for whoever feels the strongest about the naming to come to consensus about a scheme.

author: pipermerriam
content:
I'm working on launching this program publicly, probably very soon (like today or tomorrow).  

https://notes.ethereum.org/RamEyPIeRQm0Hs8TrWU-8g

Wanted to make this group aware of it and clarify one point which I don't want mis-understood.  There are a few places where I talk about applicants having access to the core developers.  My intent here is that: 1) Nobody here is making any explicit time commitment beyond what we normally opt ourselves into  2) The "access" here means being here in this Discord server and asking questions like anyone normally does in the relevant channels in combination with the program participants probably getting their own dedicated channel   3) No intent of them getting special treatment, but rather showing them how we all discuss, ask questions, etc through these public channels and that they are welcome to join that conversation.

author: holiman
content: baikal

author: holiman
content: I like xxxPerGas personally

author: timbeiko
content: So, does anyone have a strong-enough-to-block objection against using the following: `baseFeePerGas`, `feeCapPerGas` & `priorityFeePerGas` ? This way, we match the spec (which uses priority and not tip). If nothing comes up in the next ~18ish hours, I can open a PR against 1559 to add a paragraph saying these are the terms to use in the JSON RPC spec.

author: sky.cactus
content: I like those names, but don't like putting it in the EIP.

author: sky.cactus
content: The EIP is a consensus specification, not an interface specification.

author: pietjepuk
content:
I don't think the EIP should force people to use the new names, but it _is_ the first place people look if they don't want to come up with a name themselves. Might as well have a better "default" than what's there currently.
In addition, I imagine it's also very useful to have common nomenclature for discussions about the EIP, or possible future issues related to the transaction type it introduces. Which words mean which things (or vice versa) is something you could call "consensus" imo üòâ

author: sky.cactus
content: This is the point of debate that I'm desperately trying to get agreement on.  EIPs are standards, but people want them to be change control documents.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, EIPs are not currently well designed to be a centralized place for all information related to a particular change.  They are very specifically designed to be standards which each cover a very specific/narrow feature.

author: sky.cactus
content: I very much appreciate the desire for a change control documents, and I even understand why people want EIPs to be that document (because it is easier to bend an existing process than to create a new one).

author: pietjepuk
content: EIPs being standards does not preclude the standardization of nomenclature imo

author: sky.cactus
content: I just disagree that we should change our standardization process into a change control process without making that a very concious and discussed decision.

author: sky.cactus
content: We have a place for standardizating interfaces, and it isn't in the consensus EIPs.

author: sky.cactus
content: Consensus EIPs are narrowly defined to only cover consensus changes, not all of the other things that sometimes accompany them like network protocol changes, interface changese, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is a slippery slope to include non-consensus stuff in a consensus standard.  There are a million non-consensus things we *could* mention in many Core EIPs.

author: pietjepuk
content: The EIP already has names in it though? It's just about replacing them with these new ones no?

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, that is a different thing.

author: sky.cactus
content: It sounded like there was general (though weak) agreement that the spec should prefer verbosity over terseness.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, you definitely don't want to be guessing what things mean in a spec.

author: pietjepuk
content: I thought it was about replacing `maxPriorityFeePerGas` and `maxFeePerGas` (and whatever other terms are used in the EIP) with more well defined ones (at least, ones that more people feel more accurately capture what is meant by them in the EIP)

author: sky.cactus
content: The other way around.  The EIP currently has very descriptive names, but some people find them unwieldy due to their length and lack of consistency with historic variable name choices and don't want to use those verbose names for the API surface.

author: sky.cactus
content: Exception for `priority`, which has gone through many iterations because no one can find a good word to accurately capture what exactly the fee is.

author: sky.cactus
content: That one is just constant hotly debated.

author: sky.cactus
content: It was tip, then bribe, then inclusion, then priority.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe `authorFee`?

author: sky.cactus
content: Doesn't say what it is for, but it says who it is for.  ü§∑

author: pietjepuk
content:
I don't know. Things are always various shades of gray. So I feel that, even with EIPs being standards at the moment, if a very small change is needed to bring nomenclature to match, it will save a lot of headache down the line. Abbreviations is another thing of course.

I'm not sure what they do on the eth2 side, but even there I guess they try to converge on a certain nomenclature in the spec. Even if it is just to make things easier to talk about.

author: sky.cactus
content: We have a place for API standardization.  It just isn't on EIP-1559 directly.

author: pietjepuk
content:
No, I don't mean API. I mean a standard for nomenclature for people to use when talking about the EIP. Anyway, I doubt we would get much confusion when "max<>" and the equivalent with "max" in front are used interchangeably. As I said, shades of gray. In this case it may not matter much, but for the "tip" vs "priority" you probably want the EIP and the API to match up.
Either way, even for something so trivial as "max" prefix or not, I would say it makes sense to match the EIP and API where possible. It's not like the EIP uses "totalGasInBlockLimit" or anything either (but just "gasLimit", which isn't very descriptive). And then the lack of consistency (of mixing and matching names between API and EIP) starts to get at me, and I want to see it fixed üòâ

author: timbeiko
content: Where _is_ the best place to say "use X, Y and Z" in the JSON RPC spec ü§î ? It just feels bad to pin it in discord. I can leave a comment on the EthMagicians thread if that's helpful, but it definitely does not feel as official as the EIP itself.
